sentences.english: Since childhood love of art, hard-working people, self-taught.
sentences.chinese: 自幼热爱美术，勤奋过人，自学成材。

sentences.english: Before accepting regular professional oil painting training, Qin Zanjun was keen on traditional Chinese painting when he was a child.
sentences.chinese: 秦赞军在接受科班油画训练之前，自幼酷爱国画。

sentences.english: I prefer to fish at hight shcool.
Born in the south from staple food rice, for some strange pasta.
sentences.chinese: 生在南国自幼主食稻米，对面食有些生疏。

sentences.english: Anna still has the same love of fashion that she did when she was a little girl.
sentences.chinese: 安娜对时尚的热爱自幼时起就始终未曾改变。

sentences.english: Are the seeds of criminal behavior sown early in life ?
sentences.chinese: 犯罪行为的根源是否始自幼时？

sentences.english: We have been brought up to eat certain food.
sentences.chinese: 我们自幼就喜欢吃一些特定的食物。

sentences.english: Without reasons, I have ever loved pure colour, especially white dress.
sentences.chinese: 不知何故，自幼便酷爱净色，尤爱纯白色的服装。

sentences.english: He was drawn to sports from his earliest years.
He lost her parents, and follow the uncle aunt.
sentences.chinese: 自幼失去双亲的她，跟着舅舅舅妈相依为命。

sentences.english: Study the traditional Chinese painting, the university in painting, a French after learning.
sentences.chinese: 自幼研习国画，大学修读油画，后旅学法国。

sentences.english: Blessed with a tall stature and fragrant body, I am in the king's favor and entitled as fragrant concubine.
sentences.chinese: 我身材高挑丰满，自幼体有异香，被封为香妃。

sentences.english: This hath been thy manner from thy youth, that thou obeyedst not my voice.
sentences.chinese: 你自幼年以来总是这样，不听从我的话。

sentences.english: He has been living in his mother's hometown Hangzhou since childhood.
sentences.chinese: 他自幼随母亲在杭州生活。

sentences.english: Learn from his father's poetry painting managed.
sentences.chinese: 自幼随父亲徐达章学习诗文书画。

sentences.english: Yang Liang learned herbalism from his father from his childhood, and masters exquisite technology.
sentences.chinese: 杨良自幼随父学医，继承祖业，掌握了精湛的技术。

definition: to be orphaned of one's father
to be born of/to come from/family background/class origin
to be orphaned of one's father
to have lost both one's parents
family with a literary reputation (idiom); literary family
to learn a skill or art
to be keen on/to have a passion for
